title: Sacral Variability in Tailless Species: Homo sapiens and Ochotona princeps
abstract: Homo sapiens is variable in number of sacral vertebrae, and this variability can lead to obstetrical complication. This study uses the comparative method to test the hypothesis that sacral variability in H. sapiens is associated with absence of a tail. Three species of lagomorphs are studied: Ochotona princeps (N 5 271), which is tailless, and Lepus californicus (N 5 212) and Sylvilagus audubonii (N 5 206), which have tails. Results show that O. princeps has (1) higher diversity index for number of sacral vertebrae (0.49) compared to L. californicus (0.25) and S. audubonii (0.26) and (2) significantly higher percentage of individuals with the species-specific nonmodal number of sacral vertebrae (43.9%) compared to L. californicus (14.2%) and S. audubonii (15.5%). Comparison of H. sapiens (N 5 1,030; individuals of age 20-39 years) with O. princeps shows similarities between the species in diversity index (also 0.49 in H. sapiens) and percentage of individuals with nonmodal number of sacral vertebrae (37.3% in H. sapiens). Homeotic transformation best explains the results. H. sapiens and O. princeps show propensity for caudal shift at the sacral-caudal border (i.e., homeotic transformation of the first caudal vertebra to a sacral vertebra). Caudal and cranial shift among presacral vertebrae increases or decreases this propensity, respectively. Increase in number of sacral vertebrae in H. sapiens by homeotic transformation reduces pelvic outlet capacity and can be obstetrically hazardous.

body_text.text: This study considers proximate and ultimate causes of variability in number of sacral vertebrae in adult humans and obstetrical implications of that variability. The modal number of sacral vertebrae in humans is five, but approximately 7% of individuals have assimilation (i.e., fusion) of a lumbar vertebra and 30% have assimilation of a caudal vertebra with the sacrum (Tague, 2009 (Tague, , 2011 . The predominance of research on sexual dimorphism and obstetrical adaptation of the pelvis has focused on the hipbone (e.g., greater sciatic notch, pubic length, and subpubic angle; Letterman, 1941; Washburn, 1948; Singh and Potturi, 1978; Rosenberg, 1988; Tague, 1992; Walker, 2005; Small et al., 2012; Torimitsu et al., 2015) . The sacrum is less studied, but it too is sexually dimorphic. For example, the sacral ala is longer in females than males (Tague, 2007; Moffett et al., 2013) . Sacral length, which is, in part, influenced by number of sacral vertebrae, also is obstetrically important. Assimilation of a lumbar or coccygeal vertebra to the sacrum reduces pelvic outlet space and can be an obstetrical hazard (Tague 2009 (Tague , 2011 .

As noted above, humans are variable in number of sacral vertebrae, but we are not exceptional among primates in that variability. Based on Schultz (1961:17, table 4) , Homo ranks 13th among 20 genera with sample size of at least 20 individuals in the diversity index (DI) for number of sacral vertebrae (rank one is for genus with lowest DI). Williams (2012:137) computed and described DI as follows. "DI 5 1 2 P n i f 2 i [n/(n 2 1)], where f is the frequency of a single vertebral formula in a population and n is sample size. The diversity index ranges from 0 (no variation) to 1 (maximum variation).. . . Low values of this index indicate a small amount of dispersion and/or a high frequency of one formula, whereas high values indicate a large amount of dispersion and/or several medium-frequency formulae." DI for number of sacral vertebrae in Homo is 0.42. Among the seven genera with higher DIs than Homo, five are in Superfamily Hominoidea (Hylobates and Symphalangus in Family Hylobatidae, and Gorilla, Pan, and Pongo in Family Hominidae, with DIs of 0.59, 0.59, 0.57, 0.60, and 0.54, respectively) , and two are in Family Lorisidae (Nycticebus and Perodicticus, with DIs of 0.66 and 0.73, respectively; Wilson and Reeder [2005] is used for all taxonomic classification in this study). For the 12 genera with lower DI than Homo, DI ranges from 0.03 to 0.41, with one genus each in Families Galagidae, Indriidae, and Lemuridae, two in Atelidae and Cebidae, and five in Cercopithecidae. Notably, none of the hominoids, which includes Homo, has a tail. Nycticebus, "[o]ccasionally (has) a short external tail . . . but it is hidden by surrounding fur" (Hill, 1953:151) ; among 38 nonhominoid primate species reported by Russo (2015:356-357, table 1) , N. coucang is tied for second in having the relatively shortest tail. Pe. potto ranks ninth in relative shortness of the tail in this sample of 38 species. The other 12 genera in Schultz (1961:17, table 4 ) with lower DI than Homo have a tail (Hill, 1953 (Hill, , 1957 (Hill, , 1960 (Hill, , 1966 (Hill, , 1970 (Hill, , 1974 Russo, 2015) . (Hickman [1979] stated that all mammals have tails because all mammals have caudal vertebrae. For some species, the number of caudal vertebrae is reduced such that these vertebrae are present only in the body cavity, and these species are characterized as not having an external tail. In this study, species without an external tail are described as tailless. Also, for all species in this study, caudal refers to all vertebrae distal to the sacrum. Typically, coccygeal refers to rudimentary vertebrae in tailless species and caudal refers to vertebrae in tailed species; Hill [1957 Hill [ , 1960 , however, uses both terms for a species to distinguish vertebrae within [coccygeal] and outside [caudal] the body cavity.)

A generalization from these results is that primate genera without a tail or with a very short tail have higher variability in number of sacral vertebrae compared to those with (longer) tails. This study considers whether interspecific differences in variability in number of sacral vertebrae are related to absence or presence of a tail. The directional hypothesis is that species without a tail will have higher variability in number of sacral vertebrae compared to species with a tail.

In humans, increase in number of sacral vertebrae from the modal number by assimilation of a lumbar or caudal vertebra reduces pelvic outlet capacity and can be obstetrically hazardous (Tague, 2009 (Tague, , 2011 . Therefore, this study considers whether absence of a tail in humans is the ultimate cause for our variability in number of sacral vertebrae and for the derivative obstetrical complications. This hypothesis about taillessness and sacral variability is tested using the comparative method. Comparing tailless apes with tailed monkeys is not an independent analysis because Schultz's (1961) results mentioned above implicitly demonstrate this relationship. Therefore, this study tests the hypothesis using three species of lagomorphs: Lepus californicus (blacktailed jackrabbit; Family Leporidae), Ochotona princeps (American pika; Family Ochotonidae), and Sylvilagus audubonii (desert cottontail; Family Leporidae). L. californicus and S. audubonii have tails, whereas O. princeps is tailless. "[T]ail is large" in L. californicus (Best, 1996:2) ; "tail is large" in S. audubonii (Chapman and Willner, 1978:1) ; and O. princeps is "apparently tailless . . ., (but) pikas have a 'buried' tail that is longer relative to length of body than any other lagomorph" (Smith and Weston, 1990:2) . Howell (1924) and Bailey (1931) described O. princeps as tailless, but Bailey (1936:113) wrote that the species is "almost tailless." Extreme values for mean tail length and mean relative tail length (tail length[100%]/[total length 2 tail length]) for 14 samples of L. californicus, with each sample consisting of five individuals, are 75.0 mm and 101.0 mm for tail length and 14.6% and 21.0% for relative tail length (Nelson, 1909:129) ; for S. audubonii, these extreme values for 12 samples, with each sample consisting of five individuals, are 45.8 mm and 72.6 mm for tail length and 14.0% and 21.0% for relative tail length (Nelson, 1909:213) . Lyon (1904:363) reported that in Leporidae, "[t]he usual number of vertebrae in the sacrum is four; in some old individuals it is raised to five, and in some younger ones it is only three"; in Ochotonidae, "[t]he number of vertebrae entering into the formation of the sacrum . . . is four, the same as in the case of the Leporidae" (Lyon, 1904:367) .

This study presents data on sacral variability in three species of lagomorphs and in humans, and tests the hypothesis among lagomorphs that tailless O. princeps will have both higher DI in number of sacral vertebrae and higher frequency of individuals with the nonmodal number of sacral vertebrae compared to tailed L. californicus and S. audubonii. Results for tailless O. princeps are compared with those for tailless H. sapiens.

All individuals in this study were skeletonized. A decision was made in advance of data collection not to use individuals with gross pathology that may affect number of sacral vertebrae (e.g., ankylosing spondylitis; hemivertebra at lumbar-sacral border). Museum records were consulted for species designation, sex, external measurements for lagomorphs, and age at death and "race" for H. sapiens. All H. sapiens were reported as being between 20 and 39 years of age at death; age at death of lagomorphs was not known. The sample of H. sapiens was 1,030, with 691 classified racially as "black" (216 females and 475 males) and 339 as "white" (63 females and 276 males). Those classifications are inferred to refer to African and European ancestry, respectively. Lagomorph individuals were used only if there was information on specific locality from which they were obtained and if there was no mention that the individuals were held in captivity. Adult status of lagomorphs was based on evaluation of seven growth centers, including six epiphyses (heads of humerus and fibula, distal aspects of radius and ulna, and condyles of femur and tibia) and one apophysis (tuberosity of ischium). A growth center was classified as fused if there was at least one locus of unequivocal continuity of bone between epiphysis and diaphysis or between apophysis and body of ischium. These growth centers were viewed with 103 to 253 magnification. An individual was classified as "juvenile" if any one of the seven growth centers was not fused. Based on this criterion, 478 juveniles were examined: 163 L. californicus, 159 O. princeps, and 156 S. audubonii. Of this sample of juveniles, 159 individuals could be evaluated for fusion of all 14 growth centers (i.e., left and right sides of the seven bones); because of missing bones, postmortem damage, or adherent tissue, the other 319 individuals could be evaluated for fusion for a subset of growth centers, from 2 to 13. Based on growth centers that could be evaluated, all were unfused in 372 of 478 individuals. The other 106 juveniles had one or more growth centers unfused and one or more growth centers fused. Analysis of these 106 juveniles showed that the latest growth centers to fuse are head of humerus, distal epiphyses of radius and ulna, and apophysis of ischium. Eight hundred and ninety-eight other lagomorph individuals were studied. These individuals showed fusion of all growth centers that were available to evaluate, and all these individuals had an undamaged sacrum. Subsequent to collection of all data for this study and based on results of juvenile specimens mentioned above, this study limits analysis of sacral variability to those individuals for whom all four of the latest fusing growth centers (see above) were available for evaluation and all were fused (N 5 689; Table 1 ). These individuals were classified as skeletally "adult" for this study.

This study considers intraspecific and interspecific variability in numbers of sacral and presacral vertebrae. Comparison of results among studies is complicated by different criteria for distinguishing regional segments of the vertebral column. For example, some researchers distinguish thoracic from lumbar vertebrae by presence or absence of a facet for a rib head on the body or pedicle of a vertebra, whereas others use orientation of the zygapophyses (Schultz and Straus, 1945; Washburn, 1963; Bornstein and Peterson, 1966; Merbs, 1974; Aimi, 1994; Haeusler et al., 2002; Williams et al., 2016) . Researchers also differ in their classification of a vertebra that shows traits of adjoining vertebral segments. For example, Schultz and Straus (1945:602) classified a vertebra with "a rib on one side and . . . a true transverse process on the opposite side . . . as half a thoracic and half a lumbar vertebra." Other researchers, however, do not report vertebrae as half segments (Bornstein and Peterson, 1966) . Schultz and Straus (1945:603) also defined vertebrae as sacral if they had "intervertebral and sacral foramina ringed completely by bone in the adult. Actual osseous fusion is not necessary, but contact between the sacral ring portions of adjoining vertebrae, lateral to the sacral foramina, must exist in either a bony or cartilaginous state."

The present study categorizes (1) cervical vertebrae as those between the cranium and thoracic vertebrae and not having ribs; (2) thoracic vertebrae as those between cervical and lumbar vertebrae, with rib facet on the side of the vertebral body or pedicle; (3) lumbar vertebrae as those between thoracic and sacral vertebrae, without rib facets; (4) sacral vertebrae as those fused as a block between lumbar and caudal vertebrae, and with one or more vertebrae of that block having the auricular surface (i.e., not all sacral vertebrae need contribute to the auricular surface, but rather they are just part of the block of fused vertebrae; this classification is similar to that of Merbs (1974:13) : "At the lumbosacral border, . . .

[a]ny degree of non-pathologic fusion resulted in a vertebra being classified as a sacral unit. All fused units at the caudal end of the sacrum were also classified as sacral units."); and (5) caudal vertebrae as those distal to the sacrum. This study does not classify vertebrae by "half segments." Rather, a vertebra was classified as thoracic, for example, if it had a rib facet on the body or pedicle, regardless of whether the facet was unilateral or bilateral. This approach to classification follows the cranial-caudal sequence of vertebral specification. Classifying a vertebra with a rib facet on one side and a transverse process on the other side as thoracic rather than lumbar emphasizes retention of regional identity before a full boundary shift to a different type of vertebra. I chose the costal process as a principal criterion for classification of thoracic and lumbar vertebrae for several reasons. First, this project is one of a series dealing with the costal process (e.g., Tague, 2007) . Second, absence or presence of a costal facet is a nominal variable, whereas zygapophyseal orientation is an interval variable. The superior zygapophyses of the 19th vertebra in humans (modally, 12th thoracic), for example, can range from coronal to sagittal in orientation, and orientation of the contralateral zygapophyses can differ. Third, many of the vertebral columns for lagomorphs were articulated, which precluded assessment of zygapophyseal orientation at the thoracic-lumbar border.

There are three potential problems in this study with the criteria used for classifying vertebrae as sacral. First, this classification differs, in part, from that of Schultz and Straus (1945) . This study focuses on vertebral fusion and position in the vertebral column as the principal criteria for classifying vertebrae as sacral, whereas Schultz and Straus' (1945) definition allows for an unfused vertebra to be sacral. The principal criterion used in this study-fusion of vertebrae-is consistent with that of Standring (2005:749) , "The sacrum is a . . . fusion of five vertebrae," and White et al. (2012:219) , "The sacral vertebrae fuse . . . into one immobile . . . bone." Second, a lumbar or caudal vertebra assimilated with the sacrum becomes, by definition, a sacral vertebra. Assimilation can occur by intervertebral fusion at one of five loci-two transverse processes, two zygapophyses, and bodies. Even if assimilation is due to fusion at fewer than all five loci, this classification is consistent with the above statement about a full boundary shift being used for distinguishing between adjoining types of vertebrae. The reason is that emphasis in this study is on immobility of vertebrae that are part of the pelvis (i.e., the sacrum). Length, width, and curvature of this block of fused vertebrae are important variables in quantifying pelvic size and understanding obstetrical adaptation. Therefore, fusion at any one of these five loci creates full immobility between the adjoining vertebrae and, correspondingly, a full boundary shift in anatomical function. Third, the number of sacral vertebrae could change during an individual's adulthood if a lumbar or caudal vertebra secondarily fuses with the block of sacral vertebrae because of osteophytic growth. To mitigate that potential problem with H. sapiens, only younger adults were used in this study (see above).

Number of presacral vertebrae was counted for each individual, but only a subset of individuals had a complete set. I articulated vertebrae that were disarticulated to ensure that one or more vertebrae were not missing. For lagomorphs, the result was that of the 689 skeletally adult individuals, 429 (62.3%; 72.2% in L. californicus, 50.9% in O. princeps, and 67.1% in S. audubonii) had both a complete set of presacral vertebrae and undamaged sacrum.

IBM SPSS Statistics for Windows, Version 23.0 (2015) was used for all analyses: (1) Student's t test to compare sexes within species of lagomorphs for total length, tail length, and relative tail length; (2) chi-square test to compare species and sexes within species for prevalence in number of, and relationships between, sacral and presacral vertebrae (in some analyses, data for two or more categories were combined to minimize the number of contingency table cells with frequencies of zero or very low numbers); (3) Pearson's product-moment correlation coefficient to determine relationship between DI and nonmodal number of presacral vertebrae; and (4) binomial test (in Supporting Information) to determine if number of sacral vertebrae deviated from a one-to-one proportion. Level of significance was set at P 0.05 (Q). This study used multiple statistical tests, which increased the likelihood of Type I error. Therefore, this level of significance was adjusted using Benjamini and Hochberg's (1995) procedure (and this procedure is robust even when the multiple tests are not independent of one another; Benjamini and Yekutieli, 2001 ). Benjamini and Hochberg's (1995) procedure is as follows. This study performed 29 (m) statistical tests ("ST", which are numbered consecutively in Results and Supporting Information). The adjusted critical level of significance for each test equals (i/m)Q, where i 5 rank of the P value for that test among all 29 tests. Table 2 presents the adjusted critical level of significance for each of these tests; computation of adjusted critical level of significance was post hoc, after all statistical analyses were completed. ST is significant if its unadjusted P is less than or equal to the adjusted critical P. One-tailed test of significance was applied for the hypothesis that species without a tail would show higher frequency of individuals with the nonmodal number of sacral vertebrae compared to species with a tail. Two-tailed test of significance was applied to all other analyses. Table 3 presents total length, tail length, and relative tail length (see above for formula) for adult females and males in each species of lagomorph, and for the combined sample of adults, which includes individuals for whom sex is not known. Results show no significant difference between the sexes in any of these three variables (ST 1-ST 9). For the sample of all adults, mean relative tail length in L. californicus is 17.3 6 4.9% (N 5 118), O. princeps is 1.4 6 3.0% (N 5 246), and S. audubonii is 14.2 6 3.7% (N 5 122). O. princeps has been described as not having a tail (Howell, 1924; Bailey, 1931; Smith and Weston, 1990 ; but see Bailey, 1936) , and 80.9% (199 of 246) of adults in this study are tailless. Of 47 adults with tails, (1) mean tail length is 12 6 4 mm, with extreme values of 3 mm and 21 mm, and (2) mean relative tail length is 7.2 6 2.4%, with extreme values of 1.7% and 11.4%.

None of the three species of lagomorphs shows a significant difference between females and males in number of sacral vertebrae (Table 4 ; L. californicus, v 2 5 1.422, df 5 2, P 5 0.491, ST 10; O. princeps, v 2 5 0.271, df 5 1, P 5 0.603, ST 11; S. audubonii, v 2 5 0.431, df 5 1, P 5 0.512, ST 12; in this analysis, one male in O. princeps with six sacral vertebrae is combined with those with five sacral vertebrae, and two females in S. audubonii with five and six sacral vertebrae are combined with those with four sacral vertebrae). When all adults are combined, which includes individuals for whom sex is not known, the modal number of sacral vertebrae is four for L. californicus and S. audubonii and five for O. princeps. Percentage of adults with number of sacral vertebrae for each species is as follows ("S" 5 sacral): (1) L. californicus, 9.9% S 5 3, 85.8% S 5 4, and 4.2% S 5 5;
body_text.section: Modal Number of Sacral Vertebrae and Its Frequency in Lagomorphs
Modal Number of Sacral Vertebrae and Its Frequency in Lagomorphs

body_text.text: The central hypothesis in this study is that (principally) tailless O. princeps will have higher variability in number of sacral vertebrae than L. californicus and S. audubonii. DI (see above for formula) for number of sacral vertebrae is consistent with this hypothesis: 0.49 for O. princeps, 0.25 for L. californicus, and 0.26 for S. audubonii (Table 4) . As the DIs cannot be tested for a significant difference among them, an alternative approach to compare species for variability in number of sacral vertebrae is to test for a difference in prevalence of individuals with the nonmodal number of sacral vertebrae. Species with higher variability in number of sacral vertebrae will have higher frequency of individuals with the nonmodal number. (DI and frequency of individuals with nonmodal number of sacral vertebrae provide comparable information about sacral variability. For example, based on data from Schultz [1961:17, table 4 ] for 20 genera of primates with sample size of at least 20 individuals, as mentioned above, Pearson's correlation coefficient between these two variables is 0.992 [P < 0.001; ST 13].) Results show that the three species of lagomorphs differ significantly in frequency of individuals with the nonmodal number of sacral vertebrae, 14.2% for L. californicus, 43.9% for O. princeps, and 15.5% for S. audubonii (Table 4 , v 2 5 71.879, df 5 2, P < 0.001, ST 14). Partition analysis shows that L. californicus and S. audubonii are not significantly different from one another in their frequencies (Table 4 , v 2 5 0.158, df 5 1, P 5 0.691, ST 15), whereas O. princeps has a significantly higher frequency than the other two species (Table 4, v 2 5 71.776, df 5 1, P < 0.001, ST 16). Table 5 presents the number of cervical, thoracic, lumbar, and sacral vertebrae and their prevalence among the three species of lagomorphs. The modal number of presacral vertebrae for each species is 26 for L. californicus and S. audubonii and 29 for O. princeps. Numbers of presacral and sacral vertebrae are significantly related in O. princeps (v 2 5 8.466, df 5 2, P 5 0.015, ST 17; in this analysis, the one individual with 29 presacral vertebrae and six sacral vertebrae is combined with those with five sacral vertebrae) and S. audubonii (v 2 5 19.725, df 5 2, P < 0.001, ST 18); L. californicus is not included in this analysis because all variation in number of sacral vertebrae is among individuals with 26 presacral vertebrae. In O. princeps, number of sacral vertebrae Table 6 shows the prevalence of number of sacral vertebrae for H. sapiens. Differences in prevalence between black and white females and between black and white males are not significant (Table 6 , v 2 5 4.086, df 5 2, P 5 0.130 for females, ST 20; v 2 5 5.317, df 5 3, P 5 0.150 for males, ST 21; in this analysis, three females with four sacral vertebrae are combined with those with five sacral vertebrae, and in both females and males individuals with seven, eight, and nine sacral vertebrae are combined into one group). Comparison of prevalence of number of sacral vertebrae between the combined sample of females and the combined sample of males also is not significant (Table 6 , v 2 5 0.508, df 5 3, P 5 0.917, ST 22; in this analysis, individuals with seven, eight, and nine sacral vertebrae are combined into one group). Therefore, females and males are combined into a single sample (N 5 1,030) , and their modal number of sacral vertebrae is 5 (N 5 646, 62.7%). Frequencies of occurrence for other numbers of sacral vertebrae are as follows: 1.1% (N 5 11) for S 5 4; 33.9% (N 5 349) for S 5 6; 1.7% (N 5 17) for S 5 7; 0.6% (N 5 6) for S 5 8; and 0.1% (N 5 1) for S 5 9. Based on these frequencies, DI for number of sacral vertebrae in H. sapiens is 0.49, which is the same as for O. princeps (see above). H. sapiens and O. princeps also do not differ significantly from one another in sacral variability based on frequency of individuals with a nonmodal number of sacral vertebrae, with 37.3% (384 of 1,030, Table 6 ) in H. sapiens and 43.9% (119 of 271, Table 4) in O. princeps (v 2 5 3.977, df 5 1, P 5 0.046, ST 23).

body_text.section: Relationship Between Numbers of Presacral and Sacral Vertebrae

body_text.text: This study shows that (principally) tailless O. princeps has significantly higher variability in number of sacral vertebrae than tailed L. californicus and S. audubonii, but O. princeps and tailless H. sapiens do not differ significantly from one another in that variability. There are three proximate causes for variation in number of sacral vertebrae: (1) fusion of a lumbar or caudal vertebra to the sacrum due to osteophytic development; (2) intraspecific variation in number of somites; and (3) homeotic transformation. Osteophytic development is not likely the principal explanation for results of this study. Osteophytic development on vertebrae does increase with advancing age in H. sapiens (Stewart, 1958; Snodgrass, 2004; Watanabe and Terazawa, 2006; Listi and Manhein, 2012) . Tague (2009 Tague ( , 2011 also reported that fusion of a caudal vertebra, but not a lumbar vertebra, to the sacrum increases in prevalence with advancing age in H. sapiens, beginning in the fifth decade of life in males. For those reasons, the sample of H. sapiens in this study is restricted to individuals between 20 and 39 years of age; ages of lagomorphs are not known.

Intraspecific variation in number of somites is not likely the principal explanation for results of this study, although full, critical assessment of this explanation is not possible because total number of vertebrae is not known for the predominance of individuals in this study due to missing caudal vertebrae. Studies have shown that number of vertebrae is influenced by genetic and environmental factors (Berge, 1948; Lecyk, 1965; Primmett et al., 1988; Borchers et al., 2004; Alho et al., 2011) . Developmentally, if variation in somite number affected only one segment of the vertebral column, then that change should be independent of the number of vertebrae in adjoining segments. If variation in somite number affected two or more adjoining segments, then that variation would likely be in the same direction (i.e., increase or decrease in number of somites in adjoining segments). However, this study shows that increase in number of thoracic vertebrae is associated with decrease in number of lumbar vertebrae (e.g., Table 5 , 29 presacral vertebrae in O. princeps, and Table 7 , 23, 24, and 25 presacral vertebrae in H. sapiens).

Homeotic transformation is the explanation most consistent with the results of this study. Ten Broek et al. (2012:457) asserted that, "[a]ny change in the number of one or another type of vertebrae almost by definition involves homeotic transformations. . .. It is often assumed that changes of the number of vertebrae in a region do not necessarily require homeotic transformations and can be solely the result of meristic changes, however [sic] this is not true." Homeotic transformation is respecification of vertebral morphology such that the boundary between thoracic and lumbar vertebrae, for example, is shifted cranially or caudally (Wellik, 2007) . For example, and as mentioned above, among adults with the same number of presacral vertebrae, there is generally an inverse relationship between numbers of thoracic and lumbar vertebrae. Homeotic transformation at the lumbar-sacral border explains instances of nonmodal number of sacral vertebrae. For example, in H. sapiens, 75% (27 of 36, Table 7 ) of individuals with 23 presacral vertebrae (i.e., one fewer vertebra than the modal number) have six sacral vertebrae (i.e., one more vertebra than the modal number). Schultz and Straus (1945:619 ) made a similar observation that increase in number of vertebrae in one segment of the vertebral column is accompanied by a decrease in an adjoining segment:

In macaques, e.g., the modal number of 22 truncal vertebrae is formed by the combination of 19 thoracic 1 lumbar with 3 sacral segments in 83 per cent of all cases and by the combination of 18 of the former with 4 of the latter in 1 per cent. . . . In no case has there been found an increase in thoracic 1 lumbar segment combined with an increase in sacral ones, nor a decrease in the former combined with a decrease in the latter. A deviation from the modal number of sacral vertebrae can be accompanied by a deviation in the opposite direction from the modal number of thoracic 1 lumbar vertebrae or may leave the latter number unaltered, but intragenerically there never are combined increases with increases or decreases with decreases in the numbers of sacral and of thoracic 1 lumbar vertebrae. Pilbeam (2004) also concluded that homeotic transformation rather than difference in somitogenesis better explains intraspecific and interspecific variation in numbers of vertebrae among anthropoids.

This study uses three species of lagomorphs to test the directional hypothesis that absence of a tail is associated with high variability in number of sacral vertebrae. O. princeps is characterized as not having a tail (Howell, 1924; Bailey, 1931; Smith and Weston, 1990 ; but see Bailey, 1936; 80 .9% of adults in this study do not have a tail), whereas both L. californicus and S. audubonii have tails. Results lead to rejection of the null hypothesis that absence of a tail is not related to variability in number of sacral vertebrae. Compared to L. californicus and S. audubonii, O. princeps has both (1) higher DI for number of sacral vertebrae and (2) significantly higher percentage of individuals with the nonmodal number of sacral vertebrae. This study considers high variability in number of sacral vertebrae in O. princeps to be due principally to homeotic transformation at the sacral-caudal border, both separately and in conjunction with homeotic transformation in presacral vertebrae. Among individuals in O. princeps with the modal number of vertebrae for each presacral segment (i.e., seven cervical, 17 thoracic, and five lumbar vertebrae, representing 87 of 138 individuals, 63.0%), there is approximately a one-to-one proportion of sacra with four and five vertebrae (47.1% and 52.9%, respectively, which are not significantly different from one another, see Supporting Information). This bimodality implies high propensity for vertebral shift at the sacral-caudal border. This study considers the number of sacral vertebrae in absence of a shift to be four. This interpretation is consistent with that of Lyon (1904:367) who wrote that, "the number of vertebrae entering into the formation of the sacrum [in Ochotonidae] . . . is four." Caudal shift at the sacral-caudal border leads to assimilation of the 34th vertebra with the sacrum, resulting in a five-segment sacrum (see Supporting Information). H. sapiens and O. princeps are (principally) tailless. They are similar in high variability in number of sacral vertebrae: (1) DI of 0.49 in both species, and (2) no significant difference from one another in frequency of individuals with the nonmodal number of sacral vertebrae. Homeotic transformation explains their high variability in number of sacral vertebrae. Homeotic transformation at the thoracic-lumbar and lumbar-sacral borders lead to a nonmodal number of presacral vertebrae, and this study demonstrates a significant relationship between numbers of presacral and sacral vertebrae. O. princeps and H. sapiens have higher percentages of individuals with nonmodal numbers of presacral vertebrae than L. californicus and S. audubonii (17.4% [24 of 138] in O. princeps, 9.4% [96 of 1,018] in H. sapiens, 7.2% [10 of 138] in S. audubonii, and 4.6% [7 of 153] in L. californicus), and this difference between the tailless and tailed species explains, in part, the difference in variability in number of sacral vertebrae. However, this study considers the high propensity for homeotic transformation at the sacral-caudal border (i.e., assimilation of the first caudal vertebra with the sacrum) in O. princeps and H. sapiens to be the principal reason for high variability in number of sacral vertebrae in these species.

Russo's (2015) study of caudal vertebrae in mammals may provide the proximate cause for high propensity of assimilation of the first caudal vertebra with the sacrum in tailless species. Russo (2015) reported that the cranial articular surface of the first caudal vertebra differs in size and shape between tailless and tailed species, with the sacral-caudal joint being less mobile in tailless species compared to tailed species. The altered shape of the first caudal vertebra in tailless species (Russo, 2015:372, fig. 8 ) may presage its assimilation (homeotic transformation) from caudal to sacral vertebra. Although both H. sapiens and O. princeps have a high propensity for assimilation of the first caudal vertebra with the sacrum, the prevalence in H. sapiens is lower than in O. princeps. (Among individuals with the species-specific modal number of cervical, thoracic, and lumbar vertebrae [7-12-5 In H. sapiens, females with a six-segment sacrum, whether due to assimilation of a lumbar or caudal vertebra, have a significantly shorter posterior sagittal diameter of the pelvic outlet compared to females with a fivesegment sacrum (Tague, 2009 (Tague, , 2011 . Posterior sagittal diameter of the outlet is the distance between the apex of the sacrum and midpoint of the transverse diameter of the outlet (Fig. 1) . The posterior sagittal diameter represents displacement of the sacrum from the ischia, and it is markedly sexually dimorphic. Among individuals with a five segment sacrum, posterior sagittal diameter of the outlet is 14.7% longer in females than males, with mean values of 67.0 6 9 mm in females (N 5 83) and 58.4 6 7.8 mm in males (N 5 75; Tague, 2009:435, table 7 ; samples are of "blacks" and "whites" from the Hamann-Todd and Robert J. Terry Collections, and these collections are also used in this study). Among females, assimilation of a caudal vertebra with the sacrum cancels this sexual dimorphism, with these females having a mean value of 57.5 mm for the posterior sagittal diameter (Tague, 2011:432, table 7 ; 57.5 mm is the mean value of the means for "blacks," 61.4 6 9.4 mm, N 5 29, and "whites," 53.6 6 12.3 mm, N 5 28; samples are also from the Hamann-Todd and Robert J. Terry Collections). Moir (1947:22) argued that, "a[n] . . . accurate indication [of posterior outlet contraction] . . . is the size of the posterior sagittal diameter of the outlet." Based on Suonio et al.'s (1986) characterization that the posterior sagittal diameter of the outlet is contracted if it is 9% shorter than the "normal, ample" diameter, Tague (2011) reported that approximately 56% of females in his study with assimilation of the first caudal vertebra to the sacrum have an obstetrically contracted diameter. Contraction of the posterior sagittal diameter of the outlet may not singly obstruct delivery because the fetus is delivered through the subpubic space, which is part of the anterior aspect of the outlet. However, conjoint contraction of the posterior sagittal diameter with either the transverse diameter of the outlet or subpubic arch can compromise successful birth: "in cases of transverse contraction [of the pelvic outlet] . . . the possibility of spontaneous labor will depend . . . upon the space available posterior to the tubera ischii" (Williams, 1909:626;  i.e., posterior sagittal diameter); "[i]f the narrow [subpubic] arch is also associated with a forward projecting sacral tip or fused coccyx delivery may be arrested by an outlet obstruction" (Moir, 1947:23) ; and "[i]n obstructed labors caused by a narrowing of the . . . pelvic outlet, the prognosis for vaginal delivery often depends on the length of the posterior sagittal diameter of the pelvic outlet" (Cunningham et al., 2001:56) .

If assimilation of a caudal vertebra is obstetrically disadvantageous in H. sapiens, (1) why does O. princeps have a higher frequency of this assimilation? and (2) why is there not sexual dimorphism in number of sacral vertebrae in H. sapiens? In H. sapiens, the apex of the sacrum is deep in the pelvic cavity and is near the plane of the ischial tuberosities. In contrast, the apex of the sacrum in a number of other mammals does not extend distal to the ischial spines and is often proximal to the superior border of the pubis (Tague, 2005:393, fig. 1 ; Tague, 2016:506, fig. 1 ). That is, the apex of the sacrum confines the pelvic outlet in H. sapiens, whereas in many other mammals, the sacrum is not a prominent bony wall to the outlet. I did not collect data on position of the sacrum relative to the ischia in O. princeps. However, O. princeps has an unusual pelvic anatomy that facilitates parturition: a "striking feature of the pelvis in Ochotona is the absence of the symphysis pubis. The pubic bones are widely separated from one another but are connected by a ligament" (Lyon, 1904:437) . Geomys bursarius (plains pocket gopher) also does not have a pubic symphysis, and Chapman (1919) interpreted this absence as an obstetrical adaptation. If the interpubic ligament in O. princeps responds to the hormone relaxin during late pregnancy and parturition and increases pelvic joint mobility, as it does in some other mammals, then capacity of the mother's pelvis can be enlarged temporarily during birth (Hall and Newton, 1947; Talmage, 1947; Zarrow et al., 1961; Zarrow and Wilson, 1963; Hisaw and Hisaw, 1964; O'Connor et al., 1966) . In contrast with O. princeps, the pubic bones in H. sapiens form a symphysis. (L. californicus and S. audubonii also have a pubic symphysis; see Todd [1921] for discussion of differences in pubic symphyseal morphology among mammals.) The symphysis in H. sapiens increases in width during pregnancy, but only by a few millimeters (Heyman and Lundqvist, 1932; Abramson et al., 1934; Ohls en, 1973; Bj€ orklund et al., 2000) , which does not meaningfully increase pelvic capacity (Tague, 1992) . In contrast, sacroiliac joint mobility during pregnancy can meaningfully increase pelvic capacity in H. sapiens, particularly of the pelvic outlet (Borell and Fernstr€ om, 1957) . Moreover, there are three sexual size dimorphisms in H. sapiens that increase pelvic outlet capacity in females compared to males-angulation of sacrum and lateral flare of ischial tuberosities and inferior pubic rami (Tague, 1992) . Perhaps pelvic joint mobility during pregnancy and sexual size dimorphism obviate selection for a sexual difference in number of sacral vertebrae in H. sapiens. I am not aware of literature on mammals as to whether the sexes differ in number of sacral vertebrae, but species do differ in their pelvic sexual dimorphisms to achieve obstetrical adequacy (Tague, 2016) .

Although this study considers assimilation of a caudal vertebra with the sacrum in H. sapiens to be obstetrically disadvantageous, assimilation could be advantageous for support of abdominopelvic viscera. In a biped, the bony pelvis (including the pubic symphysis), pelvic floor musculature, and connective tissue help to support viscera (Barber, 2005) . Prevalence of pelvic floor disorder is inferentially associated with the size of the pelvic outlet. MacLennan et al. (2000) reported that males have a lower frequency of pelvic floor disorder than nulliparous females; correspondingly, males have a smaller pelvic outlet than females (Tague, 1992) . Also, Baragi et al. (2002) suggested that African American females have a lower rate of pelvic visceral prolapse than European American females due, in part, to a smaller pelvic outlet. The prevalence of assimilation of a caudal vertebra with the sacrum in H. sapiens may represent a compromise between opposing selection pressures on the pelvis for obstetrical adequacy and visceral support.

There are a number of issues related to taillessness, variability in number of sacral vertebrae, and obstetrical implications not addressed in this study that warrant further investigation. First, a tail is functional in a variety of ways (Hickman, 1979) , but taillessness has evolved in a diverse suite of mammals, such as Choloepus didactylus (Linnaeus's two-toed sloth; Russo, 2015), Desmodus rotundus (common vampire bat; Greenhall et al., 1983) , Macaca sylvanus (Barbary macaque; Russo, 2015) , and Microcavia australis (southern mountain cavy; Tognelli et al., 2001) . Although species likely differ in ultimate causes for taillessness, do these species have a common proximate cause for high variability in number of sacral vertebrae-high propensity for caudal shift at the sacral-caudal border associated with changes in the cranial articular surface of the first caudal vertebra? Second, are differences among species in variation in number of sacral vertebrae principally due to the dichotomy in absence or presence of a tail, or is the underlying basis for these differences continuous and based on relative tail length (Russo, 2015:365, 368, figs. 3 and 6) ? Third, this study shows that H. sapiens has high variability in number of sacral vertebrae due, in part, to caudal shift at the sacral-caudal border. However, this study suggests that obstetrical complication diminishes the frequency of this caudal shift. When in hominin evolution did selection against assimilation of a caudal vertebra begin? Evidence for tailless hominoids extends approximately to 15-18 Ma (Ward et al., 1991; Nakatsukasa et al., 2003 Nakatsukasa et al., , 2004 . However, the distal aspect of the sacrum in extant apes, and by inference in early Miocene apes, does not extend distally to the level of the ischial tuberosities and, therefore, does not confine the pelvic outlet Lovejoy, 1986, 1998) . In contrast, the apex of the sacrum does approach the ischial tuberosities in the early hominin A.L. 288-1 (Australopithecus afarensis; Lovejoy, 1986, 1998) . In A. afarensis, assimilation of the first caudal vertebra with the sacrum undoubtedly would have shortened the posterior sagittal diameter of the pelvic outlet, as it does in H. sapiens, and may have presented an obstetrical complication. Therefore, regardless of whether the modal number of sacral vertebrae in early hominins was four, five, or six (Haeusler et al., 2002; Pilbeam, 2004; McCollum et al., 2010; Russo and Williams, 2015) , whether the fifth vertebra of the sacrum in A.L. 288-1 is of sacral or caudal origin (Russo and Williams, 2015) , and whether the mechanism of birth involved rotation or nonrotation of the fetus within the pelvis (Berge et al., 1984; Lovejoy, 1986, 1998; H€ ausler and Schmid, 1995; Ruff, 1995 Ruff, , 2010 Bouhallier et al., 2004; Berge and Goularas, 2010) , perhaps one of the earliest obstetrical adaptations in hominin evolution was selection against high propensity for caudal shift at the sacral-caudal border associated with taillessness.

TABREF6.content:
Vertebral Shift at Sacral-Caudal Border
in H. sapiens
TABREF6.text: in H. sapiens and 7-17-5 in O. princeps], 36.1% [320 of 892] has six or more sacral vertebrae in H. sapiens and 52.9% [46 of 87] have five sacral vertebrae in O. princeps.) The reason for this difference may be that an elongated sacrum is obstetrically disadvantageous in H. sapiens but not in O. princeps.
